i ve taken care of lots of humans with disseminated valley fever in their brains and other organs  it s pretty rare and often there is some reason that the immune system is compromised  fluconazole is the treatment   ""
if seizures are the only symptom i would be surprised if there were  lesions  in the brain  hopefully just an inflamed meninges with can easily cause seizure activity   ""

do the fluconazole  it will take months of medication  watch for declining neuro symptoms  altered mood  gait stumbling  increased seizure activity etc   keep a log  if symptoms get worse then go to the vet  however if you really wanted to know if there are brain lesions then you could get a ct scan to confirm   ""

i don t think anti seizure meds are great because you re just masking symptoms  the meds are there though if the seizures start to effect quality of life  i am just a nurse for humans though  so i could be wrong  take care op i hope your doggo gets better  ""

i m hesitant to comment  because i don t want to crush your hope  at the same time  i was so upset that the vet made it sound like my girl jenna  5 yr old husky mix  would be okay as long as she was on the valley fever medication  to that end  every case is different but i would prepare yourself for the worst  spend as much time as you possibly can  get all the snuggles  take all the pics  do a clay imprint pawprint  and give her all the love  i m so sorry you re in this situation  ""
i had a husky who developed seizures that we managed with anti seizure meds for years  ""

then we saw a new vet  he asked about the cause which we didn't know   he tested for valley fever and it came back positive   did a long course of valley fever meds  and she got better   no more seizures  no more anti seizure meds  and she lived a long normal life afterwards without any noticeable ailments  ""
every case is different  and they don't all end poorly  ""
if it has reached their brain  i would start really working at making memories with them  feed them the stuff they love  take them to new places    ""
treatment can be successful for valley fever  but seizures are tough for any living creature  ""
valley fever can be tough especially if its in the brain  stay consistent with meds   watch for any changes in symptoms  sending love to you both ""

my dog had seizures due to masses in his lungs  he lived for over a year with fluconazole  anti seizure medication and pain meds  the masses were found by x rays or else we wouldn't have known they were there  overall  he had a good quality of life  eventually  we opted to put him down after an extended cluster seizure   ""
i'm sorry to hear about your dog  stay on top of the meds  and cherish him while you have him  ""
my dog was diagnosed with valley fever  she s had it for a few years now  she has been on fluconazole ever since  we get her labs checked regularly ""

my golden also had valley fever reach her brain  she lived around four years after diagnosis  passing away at age 11  after a couple of years of medication  we stopped treatment  she did have numerous other health issues after treatment  though   ""

a little on her story   she lost her appetite  which was very out of character  and had a slight cough  the valley fever test came back negative  but we were told it may be too early for the antibodies  not long afterward  she had six seizures overnight  it was so scary  ultimately  she tested positive for valley fever  we started the meds and she did good taking them for almost 2 years until she started refusing the medication  vet was ok stopping meds since her levels were very low  ""

i m really sorry you re going through this  my 7 yo australian shepherd caught valley fever and she fought it for about 8 months  at first it was sneezing  1 month or so   then she got weak and really skinny  2 5 months   we had her on medicine and were regularly getting blood titer    tests done  she wasn t getting better or worse during that time so we still had hope  one day she started having seizures that turned into once every other week or so  she got more meds to help fight the seizures and they seemed to be working  and my last night with her my wife called me at work and said she was having seizures again and they were lasting about 2 4 minutes every couple hours  i gave her the biggest steak i could find on my way home   ""
i can t really go on from here because i miss that pup a lot  but i wish you and you doggo the best  fuck valley fever  ""
pming the vet who is involved with a study here and knows a lot about it  ""
she is the authority on valley fever here ""

there's a pet neurologist out in east valley  i have a dog that has seizures and has had valley fever on two separate occasions  you can rule out it getting to the brain if they get an mri  pretty pricey and very helpful for peace of mind and knowing the best treatment path  seizures can just be inherent like in people  could be just bad luck  ""

you might have fido's vitamin d levels tested   vitamin d has a great effect on inflammation and immune function  afaik  dogs need fairly high blood levels of 25 d  up around 200 ng  most commercial kibble feed will not provide enough d to get them there  adding a few thousand iu of plain old d3 can help   try around 1 000 iu for every 20 pounds of body weight  there's no indication that this will outright cure valley fever  but it may well help the dog to eventually beat back the disease  ""
it looks like fungus in the brain is bad news  but not necessarily terminal   good luck to all  ""

i have had two dogs with valley fever  on year two of treating my second dog  now   both were disseminated   the first in the skin as ulcers  and now my dogs is in her joints  the first was never fully successfully treated but lived to be around 17 and had vf his whole life   ""
my current dog has been treated for 2 years  i have to change her meds every 6 months due to side effects but it is slowly decreasing in her system  she is now 7 5yo  ""

that said  if it has reached the brain  the prognosis is very poor  i say give the fluconazole a try and manage any symptoms you can in the meantime  but know that it is very very challenging to treat it at that stage  and may not be successful  ""
hugs to you my friend  they keep saying they're going to release a vaccine for pets  i hope that happens  ""

as long as you keep on with fluconazole or itraconazole religiously and understand it can take up to 3 months to see any significant change i would say you can give it a good chance  we had a dog come in with vf that didn't allow the jaw to open and seizures  6 months on fluconazole she already showed good improvement  don't give up  have patience  recheck the titer when your vet recommends  never run out of medication so always call for refills when you have at least 1 week of meds left  ""

sorry to hear about your pup's diagnosis  i fostered a dog with valley fever that had reached his brain  it made him blind and eventually led to severe aggression  it was a really stressful thing to go through  for both of us   and i did end up having to put him down   ""
he was on a high dose of fluconazole  but i think we were just too late to help him  his original owners let him suffer with vf for 2 years untreated  ""
i'm happy to share his entire medical journey while i had him if you find that helpful   feel free to dm me  ""

my family had my brother's 4 year old golden retriever  we got him meds roughly the same pint in time as you did  the seizures became a permanent fixtures in our lives  oakley survived for 2 years before a grand mal seizure happened  it happened when no humans were home yet and so we don't know exactly what happened that took him  ""
i don't say this to discourage you  dogs with seizure conditions can live a very long time if you have the ability to treat them like what they are   a disabled dog  ""

i had a dog with valley fever  and this is exactly what i would recommend   i wouldn t spend the money for a ct scan  because i don t know how seeing if there are lesions would affect treatment options    ""
treating the valley fever  and monitoring titer levels if you can  is the best course of action  your dog will most likely be fine after a long round of  treatment  ""
i d rather have it given to me straight  it s very hard to find specific info on dogs that have seizures from it and potentially have it in their brain  hence my post    ""
thank you for sharing your experience and advice  and i m so sorry for your tragic loss   ""

our emergency vet we saw didn t imply anything about a decreased lifespan  but did say care for vf would be a long term deal for most pets  she also didn t prescribe for anything for the seizures  only fluconazole  and told me to follow up with a normal vet   ""
so i m going to be pretty upset if she too didn t warn me that things have taken a turn for the worst  i d rather have the truth and be prepared  ""
mine came back negative as well  the testing does not pick up fungus until it's massive   ""
i insisted then got into a study  my neighbor's dog had just passed away due to vf  ""
thank you  è ""
who s your neuro  ""
thank you  ï ""

i'll also add that the vf had spread to his lymph nodes which would cause his airways to restrict and him to pass out  one vet incorrectly diagnosed this as him having seizures  but he really wasn't  ""
not sure if that's helpful or what your dog is experiencing  ""

honestly  i m not sure my vet expected my dog to pass so soon    3 months  after diagnosis  similar to your er vet experience  my vet didn t say anything about a shortened lifespan and prescribed fluconazole with the instruction that it would likely be lifelong medication   tg for compounding pharmacies  bc that stuff was    w out pet insurance   i sincerely hope your dog s experience is different than mine  but either way  it s good to be emotionally prepared that she may not make it long term  ""
it is awful how it affects dogs  humans  too  my parents had a friend pass away from vf  ""
hope she can help ""

phoenix  az 85040 ""
it is bad in my area  the only reason i managed to save my dog was because my nextdoor neighbors had recently passed away  ""
my dogs test was negative but she had stopped eating and started coughing  ""
i was in the university study here and the testing does not pick up the fungus fast enough  thank goodness i coughed ellas  it's been close to two years now and she is doing wonderful  ""
i insisted on giving her the meds and so glad i did  ""
also recommend vet neuro   they are pricey but good  ""
also look into amphotericin   had a dog with really bad vf  no seizures though  who didn t respond to fluconazole  she really did well with amphotericin and i do think it saved her life  ""

rustlers roost on south mountain fits the vibe  but if you are willing to travel  hit whiskey row in prescott  'the palace restaurant and saloon' might be what you are after  everyone is in old school garb and while the food is not gourmet     the history inside and overall environment are incredible  other stuff in walking distance with same decor  stay at hotel st michael  so much history  ""

the town of jerome is a former mining ghost town that's had a resurgence in recent years  and now has restaurants  shops  etc  downtown cottonwood also has lots of fun stores and really good restaurants  ""

the oldest restaurant and oldest bar in the state is the palace saloon in prescott  the earps and doc holiday drank there  and the story goes that when the building caught fire in the late 1800s  the patrons picked up the beautiful  carved wood bar  carried it across the street to the town square where it stayed until the saloon was rebuilt  then the bar was carried back in   downtown prescott is also a lot of fun to visit  vibrant town square   ""
for the full experience  go down to tombstone and bisbee  ""
goldfield ghost town ""
pinnacle peak steakhouse  https   www pinnaclepeaktucson com  in tucson totally fits this vibe  hang out afterwards for a shoot out show  ""

like if there was a spigot or something  provided by the operator of the campground  like a state or national park  blm  county  etc   it s pretty popular at larger campgrounds that have other amenities  like hookups for trailers and rvs  pit or flushable toilets  fire rings  picnic tables  etc ""
rv campgrounds have water and electric hookups at every site  you usually only hear the term dry camping from rv people  it s basically just another term for dispersed camping ""

this is good news  there is no way c s grocery wholesalers would be able to manage a large national chain of stores if the merger and divestiture of safeway albertsons stores were to go through  safeway pulled the exact same shit in the pnw when they merged with albertsons and divested some of the stores to haggen  which was more like an aj's level grocery store than your standard frys or safeway store  they also talked up haggen's ability to handle the stores  but in about 6 months haggen was bankrupt  and safeway albertsons bought the divested stores back for pennies on the dollar  which made competition even worse than before  i can almost guarantee that c s wholesale's reach was exceeding it's grasp with the labels and stores that kroger and safeway wanted to sell off to them   c s would also flounder  and guess who'd be there to buy back all the stores they had divested  and reduce competition even more   big loser deal for consumers  ""
